newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Morocco sees GDP growth up to 3.0 pct in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Morocco sees GDP growth up to 3.0 pct in 1997.

text.p: Moroccan Finance Minister Mohammed Kabbaj, presenting the 1997/98 draft budget to parliament, expects the economy to grow by up to 3.0 percent this year, the official MAP news agency said on Thursday.

Kabbaj, speaking before the 333-seat Chamber Representatives, was quoted by MAP as saying: "The 1997/98 draft budget was prepared on the basis of a forecast of GDP growth up to 2.0 to 3.0 percent this year and strong growth in 1998."
The draft was earlier approved by a ministerial meeting presided by King Hassan II, MAP said.
"The government also expects an inflation rate of 4.0 percent in 1997 against 3.0 percent in 1996, due to an expected increase of households consumption," MAP quoted Kabbaj as saying.

A copy of the draft law, which was obtained by Reuters, showed the state total budget rose to 126.7 billion dirhams ($13.5 billion) in the 1997/98 fiscal year compared with 117.1 billion dirhams ($12.4 billion) in 1996/97.
The 1997/98 total state receipts stand at 114.3 billion dirhams compared with 107.7 billion dirhams in the previous fiscal year.
"The budget deficit stands at 12.4 billion dirhams in 1997/98 fiscal year, up from 9.4 billion dirhams in the previous period," the ministry said.
